newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Petroz says may need capital raising.
newsitem.headline: Petroz says may need capital raising.

text.p: Oil and gas explorer and producer Petroz NL said on Wednesday it may need to raise capital to fund part of its share of the Undan/Bayu development, but said any raising would not be large.
"Maybe there will be a need for some portion of new equity, but it won't be a devastating amount," Petroz managing director Rod Brown told a Securities Institute of Australia address.
Brown said Petroz's share of the cost of developing the Timor Sea field would be about A$150 million for the liquids project and A$100-A$150 million for an additional LNG project.
Brown said he did not believe Petroz, which is currently debt free, would have any difficulty funding the project.
A large part would be project financed and banks had already been "knocking on our door".
Some of the smaller participants might band together to get cheaper project finance, he added.
Petroz would also have a projected cash flow of about A$20 million a year from the development of the nearby Elang-Kakatua fields in 1998.
Brown later told reporters that any capital raising would not be large relative to Petroz's market capitalisation, currently around A$226 million.

First liquids production at Bayu-Undan was expected about mid-2001, while a longer development period for the LNG project would see it come on stream about a year later, assuming no delay in securing markets, he said.
BHP holds a 42.417 percent stake of the ZOCA 91-12 Undan permit, while Phillips Petroleum Co, leads the ZOCA 91-13 Bayu consortium with a 60 percent stake.
The participants in ZOCA 91-12 besides BHP are Santos Ltd with 21.426 percent, Indonesia's Inpex Sahul with 21.209 percent and Petroz with 14.948 percent.
In the adjacent ZOCA 91-13 permit, the other participants besides Phillips are Oryx Energy Co with 25 percent and Hardy Oil & Gas Plc with 15 percent.
